Graphical abstract Sulfuration-strategy enhances OER activity of the SACs. 3D carbon shells improve hydrophobicity of Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC, promoting effective gas–liquid-solid interface. Above modification optimizes spin-state and adsorption-energy of oxygen adsorption intermediates, leading excellent electrocatalytic activity and ZABs performance. Development of a high-performance bifunctional catalyst is essential for the actual implementation of zinc-air batteries in practical applications. Herein, a bifunctional cathode of Co3S4/FeS heterogeneous nanoparticles embedded in Co/Fe single-atom-loaded nitrogen-doped carbon nanosheets is designed. Cobalt-iron sulfides and single atomic sites with Co-N4/Fe-N4 configurations are confirmed to coexist on the carbon matrix by EXAFS spectroscopy. 3D self-supported super-hydrophobic multiphase composite cathode provides abundant active sites and facilitates gas–liquid-solid three-phase interface reactions, resulting in excellent electrocatalytic activity and batteries performance, i.e., an OER overpotential (η 10) of 260 mV, a half-wave potential (E 1/2) of 0.872 V for ORR, a ΔE of 0.618 V, and a discharge power density of 170 mW cm−2, a specific capacity of 816.3 mAh g−1. DFT analysis shows multiphase coupling of sulfide heterojunction through single-atomic metal doped carbon nanosheets reduces offset on center of electronic density of states before and after oxygen adsorption, and spin density of adsorbed oxygen with same spin orientation, leading to weakened charge/spin interactions between adsorbed oxygen and substrate, and a lowered oxygen adsorption energy to accelerate OER/ORR. Keywords Zn-air battery Superhydrophobic interface Metal sulfide Heterostructure Spin density 1 Introduction In response to increasing energy demands and environmental pollution concerns, various energy conversion/storage technologies have been developed, including alkali metal batteries, fuel cells and metal-air batteries [1–3]. Zinc-air batteries (ZABs) are widely considered as next-generation energy storage device arising from their high theoretical energy density (up to 1086 Wh kg−1), intrinsic safety, environmental friendliness, and low cost [4,5]. The discharging and charging processes at the air cathode involve oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [6]. The oxygen catalytic activity of air cathodes greatly affects the power density and cycling durability of ZABs. Although noble metal electrocatalysts such as Pt and Ru/Ir based oxides are considered as the benchmark electrocatalysts for ORR and OER, respectively, their scarcity, high cost and poor stability severely limit their wide practical applications [7]. Therefore, development of non-precious metal ORR/OER bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts with suitable electrode microstructure, high bifunctional oxygen activity and excellent stability is particularly urgent for high performance and durable ZABs. In recent years, transition metal oxides, hydroxides, sulfides, phosphates, carbon-based materials, transition metal-nitrogen-carbon materials (M−N−C) and their hybrids have been well investigated for oxygen electrocatalysts [8–10]. Transition metal sulfides (TMSs) are considered as potential OER electrocatalysts due to their variable valence states and superior OER activity. However, they still face the challenges of poor ORR activity and excessive hydrophilicity in ZABs applications [11–14]. Recently, transition metal-based single atomic catalysts (SACs) have shown great potential in ZABs area due to their amazing ORR catalytic activity [15–17]. While the OER activity of most transition metal SACs is still far from satisfactory. Though transition metal sulfides and single atom catalyst have been well investigated alone in previous reports, the integration of transition metal sulfides and single atomic metal species into a composite with excellent bifunctional activity is still a great challenge [18–20]. The charge and spin interactions have attracted more and more attention in oxygen-based catalysis process in recent years. Optimization of the interaction between the adsorbed substance and the reactive sites by the charge/spin interaction strength is essential for the design of high-performance catalysts [21–24]. In the OER/ORR-dominated field of oxygen electrocatalysis, the electron transfer exhibits highly spin-dependent features because the ground state of the O2 molecule is a triplet state, accounting for the paramagnetic of O2 [25–27]. The participation of triplet state O2 in either OER or ORR requires spin-dependent electron transfer along these oxygen reactions, which plays an important role in the reaction kinetics. However, the studies on charge/spin-modulated oxygen electrocatalysis are scarcely reported, and the charge/spin regulation mechanisms remain unclear [28–30]. Meanwhile, the discharge process of ZABs corresponds to the ORR process of the cathode dominated by oxygen diffusion. The concentrations of oxygen on the electrode surface are strongly correlated with the ORR rates, which in turn impacts the power density of ZABs [6]. As such, increasing the oxygen transport rates on the catalytic electrode is an effective way to improve the power density of ZABs. Previous studies have demonstrated that air cathode with surface hydrophobic characteristics would largely enhance the ORR kinetics and performance of ZABs [31–34]. Three-dimensional self-supported multiphase composite air cathode with super-hydrophobicity provides abundant accessible active sites and facilitates the gas–liquid-solid three-phase interface reactions. Herein, we report a bifunctional composite catalyst of bimetallic sulfide nanoparticles embedded in atomic Co/Fe doped carbon nanosheets, i.e., Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC, by a gas-phase metal–organic coordination, high-temperature pyrolysis, and subsequent sulfidation strategy. This bifunctional multiphase composite catalyst could provide a number of active sites for both OER and ORR process, wherein the graphitized NCNS with Co-N x /Fe-N x atomic sites contributes to ORR activity, while the Co3S4/FeS heterostructure nanoparticles take the task of catalyzing OER processes. Particularly, the sulfide-composite exhibits super-hydrophobic feature, which is beneficial to oxygen mass transfer and construction of an efficient gas–liquid-solid three-phase interface during the electrochemical reaction. Furthermore, the multiphase composite/doping strategy could optimize the catalyst electronic structure by charge/spin modulation, resulting in enhancement of the oxygen electrocatalytic activity. As a result, the as-fabricated composite catalyst delivers outstanding bifunctional oxygen activity with a low potential gap (ΔE) of 0.618 V and excellent ZABs performance. Further DFT calculations reveal that the coupling of bimetallic sulfide nanoparticles with atomic metal sites could lead a higher density of valence electron orbital states near the Fermi surface of the cobalt-iron sulfide. At the same time, the adsorbed oxygen has a moderate spin density in the same spin direction as the metal atoms, optimizing the adsorption strength of the adsorbed intermediate O*, leading to a lower oxygen adsorption energy and faster reaction kinetics. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of CoFeZn precursor nanosheet arrays In a typical procedure, 1125 mg of urea, 175 mg of ammonium fluoride, 310 mg of zinc nitrate hexahydrate, 620 mg cobalt nitrate hexahydrate, and 430 mg ferric nitrate nine hydrate were dissolved in 37.5 mL deionized water. One piece of acid pre-treated carbon cloth (2 cm × 5 cm) with one side taped and the above solution was transferred to the PTFE reactor for hydrothermal growth at 90 °C for 7 h before being removed, cleaned with deionized water, and dried in a 65 °C oven. 2.2 Preparation of Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC The above precursor samples were heated at a rate of 5 °C min−1 for 2 h in air at 250 °C to cause mild oxidation. After being chilled to room temperature, the sample was placed in a single-way tube that contained 0.2 g of 2-methylimidazole quartz boat. Notice that the sample was positioned at downstream of 2-methylimidazole and then heated to 350 °C for 65 min, followed holding by 20 min of gas phase reaction and chilled to room temperature. The sample obtained above was put in a quartz tube, heated to 800 °C for 160 min, pyrolyzed for 2 h in an atmosphere of argon, and then cooled to room temperature. To obtain the Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC, as-prepared sample was inserted in a single-way tube with a quartz boat containing 50 mg sulfur powder. It should be noted that the sample was placed downstream of sulfur powder. The sample was then heated to 350 °C for 70 min, reacted for 60 min in Ar atmosphere and cooled to room temperature. 2.3 Preparation of Co3S4@Co/NC, FeS@Fe/NC and Co3S4/FeS Co3S4@Co/NC and FeS@Fe/NC were obtained in the same process as Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC except that the molar ratio of Co/Fe was controlled as 1:0 and 0:1 respectively during the hydrothermal growth of nanosheets. Co3S4/FeS can be obtained in the same process as Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC except without the processes of 2-methylimidazole reaction and high temperature cracking. 3 Results and discussion The fabrication processes of Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC are schematically illustrated in Fig. 1 (a). First, CoFeZn precursor nanosheets are hydrothermally grown on carbon cloth in Co2+, Fe3+, and Zn2+ solution environment. SEM images in Fig. S1(a–c) demonstrate that CoFeZn precursor nanosheet arrays are uniformly distributed on each carbon fiber. For comparison, CoZn and FeZn precursor nanosheet arrays were also prepared (as shown in Fig. S1d–i). The precursor nanosheet arrays were then pre-oxidized in air to maintain the array structure, and gas phase reacted with 2-methylimidazole vapor in argon atmosphere to form metal organic frameworks (MOF) structure [35]. The obtained sample was further subjected to high temperature pyrolysis and sulfated in argon atmosphere to obtain Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC, Co3S4@Co/NC and FeS@Fe/NC (Fig. 1b, c and Fig. S2a–f). During pyrolysis, MOFs spontaneously aromatized to create highly graphitized NCNS with Co-N x /Fe-N x single-atomic sites, and the high-temperature reduced Co/Fe nanoparticles were sulfated to form Co3S4/FeS heterostructure. Zinc species are evaporated at high temperatures and form a large number of micropores in the nanoparticles, which improves the dispersion of cobalt-iron species and increases the specific surface area [36]. As shown in Fig. 1(b and c), the nanosheet morphologies are well maintained, and obvious nanoparticles can be observed in the carbon nanosheets. In the absence of 2-methylimidazole gas reaction and high-temperature pyrolysis steps in the preparation of Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC, we obtained Co3S4/FeS nanosheets (Fig. S2g–i). The main physical phases of Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC were determined by XRD. Most of the XRD peaks in Fig. 1(d) belong to the C (002) of carbon substrate, Co3S4 (220) and FeS (011)/(020)/(131), respectively. A large carbon cloth background peak appears at 25° to 30°, accompanied by some test signal noise. The microstructure of Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC was examined by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (Fig. S3a and b), which indicated a considerable number of ultrafine nanoparticles embedded in the carbon sheets. The EDX spectrum and TEM elemental mapping in Fig. S3(c and d) and Table S1 show the elemental composition and uniform elemental distribution of Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC. High-resolution TEM images (Fig. 1e and f) indicated that Co3S4 and FeS nanoparticles were anchored in the graphitic carbon layer, with crystal facet spacings of 3.34, 2.02, and 3.38 Å corresponding to the Co3S4 (220), FeS (131), and C (002) crystal facets, which is consistent with the results of XRD. Co3S4 and FeS coexist in Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC, forming a heterogeneous interface under carbon coating. The STEM image in Fig. 1(g) clearly shows the atomic Co/Fe (white dots) dispersed in carbon nanosheets at a high density. The interfacial charge transfer and the coupling effect between different components induced by the heterogeneous structure would improve the catalytic activity. The chemical composition and electronic states of the main elements in Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC were characterized by XPS. The overall XPS spectra in Fig. S4 and Table S2 confirm the chemical elements contained in Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC, including C, N, O, Co, Fe and S. The high-resolution Co 2p XPS spectrum in Fig. 2 (a) consists of typical 2p 1/2 and 2p 3/2 peaks and can be decoupled into Co3+ (778.85 and 793.50 eV), Co2+ (781.85 and 797.82 eV), and satellite peaks (784.98 and 803.60 eV), indicating the presence of a small amount of metal cobalt that has not yet been fully sulfurized and the oxidation state may be related to the surface oxidation of cobalt or the coordination of nitrogen [37–39]. Similar to Co 2p, the high-resolution XPS spectrum of Fe 2p (Fig. 2b) can be decomposed into Fe2+ (712.25, 723.92 eV) and Fe3+ (714.49, 727.09 eV), indicating the possible presence of ferrous sulfide or Fe-N x coordination bonds [39]. The high-resolution S 2p XPS spectrum is shown in Fig. 2(c). The characteristic peaks of C–S–N (164.96 eV), S2− (163.77 and 168.61 eV), and sulfate (169.29 eV) can be detected, indicating the presence of metal sulfide and sulfur doping in carbon composition [40]. In addition, the high-resolution C 1s XPS spectrum (Fig. 2d) shows the presence of C–C (284.51 eV), C=C (285.00 eV) and C–N (285.94 eV), indicating that the carbon composition is richly N-doped and highly graphitized [41]. The high-resolution N 1s XPS spectrum is shown in Fig. 2(e), which can be fitted to obtain three characteristic peaks of Pyridine N (398.61 eV), Pyrrole N (399.71 eV), and Graphite N (401.45 eV). The Graphite N and Pyrrole N have n-type doping properties, but the pyridine N has p-type doping characteristics. The electron-donating graphite nitrogen and pyrrole nitrogen can be regarded as the active catalytic site for ORR, and the electron-withdrawing pyridine N can be regarded as the active site for OER. In O 1s spectrum (Fig. 2f), two peaks, M−O−C (531.4 eV) and M−OH/SO (532.5 eV), can be observed, which may be due to the partial oxidation of the metal Co/Fe [42–44]. The electronic structure and local environment of Co/Fe atoms in Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC were investigated using X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS). Fig. 3 (a and b) show the Co/Fe K-edge X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) of Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC and reference materials respectively. The Co/Fe K-edge absorption of Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC located between Co/Fe foil and Co3O4/Fe2O3, indicating that the Co/Fe in Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC is in oxidized states ranging from 0 to + 3. Fourier transform k 3-weighted extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectra in Fig. 3(c and d) show that the coordination environments of Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC and cobalt phthalocyanine/iron phthalocyanine (CoPc/FePc) are similar. Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC shows a prominent peak at around 1.90 Å/1.91 Å, located between the Co-N/Fe-N scattering path of the first shell layer of CoPc/FePc and the Co–Co/Fe–Fe scattering path of the first shell layer of Co/Fe Foil, suggesting the coexistence of Co–N/Fe–N and Co–S/Fe–S in Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC [45]. The wavelet transform (WT) EXAFS is a potent method for differentiating backscattered atoms based on their elemental characteristics [46,47]. Fig. 3(e and f) illustrate that WT contour maps of Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC show a single maximum intensity value in k-space at around 8.3/8.2 Å−1, attributed to Co/Fe–N species and cobalt/iron sulfide, distinguishing it from WT plots of Co/Fe foil and CoPc/FePc, confirming the presence of atomic Co/Fe and Co/Fe sulfides in Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC. As shown in Fig. 3(g and h), Figs. S5, S6 and Table S3, the EXAFS fits indicate that the first Co–N/Fe–N scattering paths of Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC have a coordination number of four, implying the presence of CoN4/FeN4 configuration in the core Co/Fe site of Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC [10]. To achieve high catalytic efficiency during the charging and discharging of ZABs, effective three-phase interface and fast oxygen diffusion at the air electrode are required (Fig. 4 a) [48]. As shown in Fig. 4(b), Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC had a contact angle of 140.2°, and the Co3S4/FeS was extremely hydrophilic due to the absence of carbon cladding, indicating that the carbon nanosheet microstructures grown on carbon cloth had excellent hydrophobicity, which is a desired property for ZABs. The relatively low content of N–C species (Fig. 2d) may also contribute to the low hydrophobicity to Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC [49,50]. The cross-section view of the air cathode during OER was analyzed by optical microscopy. O2 bubbles released from the electrode interface immediately diffuse to the electrolyte within 0.13 s. In contrast, O2 bubbles are immobilized on the surface of the Pt/C-RuO2 electrode for up to 6.0 s (Fig. 4c), indicating that the diffusion of O2 at the interface is hindered. The gaseous oxygen concentration on the Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC and Co3S4/FeS electrodes was simulated using the finite element method to further reveal the key role of the hydrophobic air electrode in facilitating O2 diffusion. The simulation results show that the O2 concentration gradient at the hydrophobic Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC electrode is significantly higher than that at the hydrophilic Co3S4/FeS electrode (Fig. 4d). Hydrophobic aerophilic surface weakens the water flooding effect between the electrode and electrolyte, increasing the oxygen content and oxygen concentration gradient in the electrolyte on the electrode side, and promote the formation of an effective three-phase interface. These results corroborate that the improvement of hydrophobic and aerophilic properties of the air electrode can effectively accelerate the diffusion of oxygen at the three-phase interface. The OER performances of Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC, Co3S4@Co/NC, FeS@Fe/NC, Co3S4/FeS and the benchmark RuO2 catalysts were assessed using linear scanning voltammetry (LSV) measurements in 1.0 M KOH with a scanning rate of 5 mV s−1. As is shown in Fig. 5 (a) and Fig. S7 (a), the polarization curves demonstrate that Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC only requires an overpotential of 260 mV to generate a current density of 10 mA cm−2 (η = E 10−1.23 V), which is lower than that of Co3S4/FeS (311 mV), Co3S4@Co/NC(322 mV), FeS@Fe/NC(354 mV) and slightly higher than RuO2 (223 mV), but exhibit higher current density at high potential. Furthermore, the Tafel slope for Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC is 45.34 mV dec−1, which is lower than Co3S4/FeS (62.93 mV dec−1) and RuO2 (87.71 mV dec−1) (Fig. S8a). These results indicate that Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC has higher OER electrocatalytic activity as well as rapid reaction kinetics [51]. The ORR performance of the prepared catalysts was assessed using the rotating disk electrode (RDE) technique at 1600 r min−1 in oxygen-saturated 1.0 M KOH electrolyte [52]. Fig. S10 shows the cyclic voltammograms (CVs) of Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC and Co3S4/FeS. For the Ar-saturated electrolyte, no oxygen-related reduction peaks were observed in CVs. However, significant oxygen reduction peaks appeared in the O2-saturated Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC electrolyte at 1600 r min−1, suggesting that Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC electrodes have excellent ORR intrinsic activity. The LSV experiments demonstrate that Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC has a half-wave potential (E 1/2) of 0.872 V, which is higher than that of Co3S4/FeS, Co3S4@Co/NC(0.832 V), FeS@Fe/NC(0.730 V) and commercial Pt/C (0.854 V), as shown in Fig. 5(b) and Fig. S7(b). And we extracted and performed ORR tests for powdered Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC (E 1/2 = 0.870 V) and Pt/C (E 1/2 = 0.842 V) in 0.1 M KOH (Fig. S9). Furthermore, the Tafel slope of 45.00 mV dec−1 for Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC is superior to Co3S4/FeS (83.63 mV dec−1) and Pt/C (55.40 mV dec−1) catalysts (Fig. S8b), indicated the faster ORR kinetic process of Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC catalyst. LSV curves in O2-saturated electrolyte were measured at different rotational speeds to elucidate the ORR four-electron reaction mechanism of the Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC catalyst (Fig. 5c). The Koutecky-Levith (K-L) diagram [53] of Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC displayed a strong linear connection (Fig. 5d), and the electron transfer number per O2 (n) was 4.204. The electron transfer number slightly greater than 4 may be due to the lower accuracy of the LSV testing method for self-supported carbon cloth based materials at different rotational speeds compared to the RRDE testing for powder materials. But overall, the self-supported Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC electrode of the ORR has a nearly four-electron route [54]. The stability of catalysts is an important concern for practical applications. For the Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC, Pt/C, and RuO2, OER and ORR polarization tests were conducted both before and after 3000 CV cycles (1.196–1.496 V vs. RHE, 50 mV s−1, 25 °C in 1.0 M KOH for OER. 0.615–1.015 V vs. RHE, 50 mV s−1, 25 °C, 200 r min−1 in O2-saturated 1.0 M KOH for ORR) [55]. The Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC demonstrates increased durability for both OER and ORR tests. The E 10 and E 1/2 of Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC only degraded by 18 and 5 mV under accelerated durability tests (ADT) for OER and ORR, which is superior to that of Pt/C (ΔE 1/2 = 15 mV) and RuO2 (ΔE 10 = 78 mV) (Fig. 5e and f). The structural morphological evolution of Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC during OER/ORR durability tests was observed by SEM and XPS. During the OER process, from the SEM images in Fig. S11(a and b), significant morphology change can be observed due to severe surface reconstruction. As is shown by the SEM images in Fig. S11(c and d), Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC self-supported electrode underwent a stability test without appreciable morphological change after ORR tests, demonstrating a robust structural stability. XPS analysis showed that M−OH/SO (531.42 eV) and M−O−C (532.51 eV) peaks in O 1s fine spectrum still exist, whereas the characteristic signals appearing at 530.8 and 529.6 eV correspond to the formation of M−O and O2− in the reconfiguration of derivatized metal oxyhydroxides (Fig. S12a). After OER, the high-resolution S 2p spectrum has only sulfate-related peak at 169.2 eV and weakened peak of S2− at 163.77 eV, while the characteristic peaks attributed to S2− and C–S–N at 168.61 and 164.96 eV almost disappear (Fig. S12b). And the increase in the content of high-valent Co/Fe elements and peaks of metal-nitrogen coordination suggests that some of the metal elements were further oxidized (Fig. S12c and d) [56]. XPS results indicate that, the valence states of both Co and Fe increase in OER, as the ratio of Co3+/Co2+ rises from 0.33 to 0.77 and Fe3+/Fe2+ elevates from 0.79 to 1.57. The above changes prove that in OER, partial sulfides in Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC undergo surface reconstruction and convert to oxyhydroxides, i.e., CoOOH and FeOOH, which are considered as the activity origin towards OER. A portion of Co3+ is converted to Co2+, and the change in the Fe component is less pronounced. Abundant lattice defects formed after self-reconfiguration will provide sufficient sites with high intrinsic activity for reactions with oxygen-related intermediates, thus accelerating electrochemical processes [40]. The bifunctional oxygen activity is typically described using the potential gap ΔE (E 10−E 1/2) as an indication [57]. The ΔE of Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC is only 618 mV, significantly lower than that of Co3S4/FeS, and only marginally higher than that of the 20% Pt/C-RuO2 catalyst (600 mV) used as a reference (Fig. 5g). Additionally, Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC has high bifunctional catalytic activity and is comparable to the most advanced bifunctional catalysts, as listed in Fig. 5(h) [49,58–66]. To reveal the underlying mechanism in OER/ORR activity improvement in Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC, we performed a comparative DFT calculation of Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC, Co3S4@Co/NC, FeS@Fe/NC, Co3S4/FeS, Pt-111, and RuO2-110. To find the most appropriate structure models, total energies and forces were optimized, and the relaxed structures and calculated results of various O–adsorption intermediates (HOO*, O*, and HO*) are displayed in Supporting Information (Figs. S13, S14 and Table S4). Noting that both the charge and spin densities are considered in our calculations. Fig. 6 (a), Fig. S15 and Table S5 show the calculated charge density differences and spin densities of O/HO adsorbed on Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC, Co3S4@Co/NC, FeS@Fe/NC, Co3S4/FeS. The charge of the adsorbed intermediate O*/ HO* in the rate-limiting step of the reaction is mainly migrated toward the sulfur and oxygen atoms, while the spin density is mainly distributed on the cobalt and iron ions, and the adsorbed oxygen atoms also have a certain spin density due to the exchange interactions between spins of oxygen atoms and these transition metal ions. The coupling between the bimetallic sulfide nanoparticles via atomic metals doped carbon nanosheets makes the O/HO adsorbed on Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC having a lower spin density in the same spin direction as the metal atoms (0.054 μB, 0.076 μB), indicating a weaker exchange interaction with the substrate, thus resulting in a lower adsorption energy and facilitating the rapid OER/ORR process [11]. As shown in Fig. 6(b) and Table S6, the Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC indeed has a weaker adsorption energy of O/HO intermediates (ΔE 1 = −4.5105 eV, ΔE 2 = −3.6924 eV), supporting rapid OER/ORR reaction. Furthermore, based on the outcomes of the experiments, the DFT calculations were applied to investigate the four-electron reaction routes (details of the calculations can be seen in the Supporting Information). Gibbs free energy diagrams of OER/ORR in all configurations were developed in order to examine the mechanism of high OER/ORR activity, which includes four primary reactions (O2, HOO*, O*, and HO*), as depicted in Fig. 6(c and d). Theoretical overpotentials of ORR and OER (η OER and η ORR) are usually used as the ORR/OER activity evaluation standard for a catalyst [67,68]. The smaller theoretical overpotential values suggest the better ORR/OER catalytic activity. It can be seen that the overpotential of Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC (η OER = 0.61 V) is lower than that of Co3S4@Co/NC (η OER = 1.17 V), FeS@Fe/NC (η OER = 0.63 V), Co3S4/FeS (η OER = 2.07 V) and RuO2-110 (η OER = 1.21 V). ORR is the inverse process of OER, and it is easy to obtain the free energy diagram of the four basic steps of a typical ORR [69,70]. The ORR overpotential of Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC is 0.51 V, which is much lower than that of Co3S4@Co/NC (η ORR = 0.53 V), FeS@Fe/NC (η ORR = 1.11 V), Co3S4/FeS (η ORR = 2.50 V) and Pt-111 (η ORR = 0.69 V). As shown in Fig. 6(e and f), Fig. S16 and Table S7, before and after O/HO adsorption, the total density of states center of Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC has a smallest negative shift (ΔE c1 =−0.0341 eV, ΔE c2 = −0.0103 eV), indicating a weakest charge interaction between the oxygen atom and the substrate, leading to the lowest oxygen binding energy. The above results indicate that the coupling of Co/Fe sulfide heterojunction nanoparticles through atomic metals doped carbon nanosheets can weaken the charge/spin interactions between adsorbed oxygen and active sites, and lower the oxygen adsorption energy, as a result in promoting the OER/ORR activity. To demonstrate the possibility for practical application of Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC-based ZABs, we assembled liquid flow ZABs employing Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC, Zn foil, and 6.0 M KOH containing 0.2 M Zn(CH3COO)2 as the air cathode, anode, and electrolyte, respectively, as shown in the inset of Fig. 7 (a). For comparison, reference ZAB employing Pt/C and RuO2 with a mass ratio of 1:1 was also fabricated. Compared to Pt/C-RuO2 air cathode (1.32 V), liquid ZAB based on Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC had an open-circuit potential (OCP) of 1.34 V (Fig. S17). As is shown in Fig. 7(a), the specific capacity of Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC based ZABs at 10 mA cm−2 is 816.3 mAh g−1, which is comparable to the Pt/C-RuO2 air cathode based ZABs (780.4 mAh g−1). Many reported research works have also measured actual specific capacities higher than the theoretical specific capacity (820.0 mAh g−1), which may be due to the excess Zn provided by the anode zinc foil [39]. Moreover, the peak power density of Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC-based battery is 170 mW cm−2, which is greater than that of Pt/C-RuO2-based battery (114 mW cm−2), as illustrated in Fig. 7(b). As depicted in Fig. 7(c), the Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC-based ZABs maintained constant charging (2.00 V) and discharging (1.18 V) voltages under 5 mA cm−2 for more than 2040 cycles (more than 680 h), indicating its superior cycling durability. Moreover, the Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC electrocatalyst also exhibits stable constant current charge–discharge curve (1.08–2.08 V for more than 210 h, 630 cycles) at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. S18). The bifunctional intrinsic activity and gas–liquid-solid three-phase interface optimized by super-hydrophobic composite structure greatly promote the OER/ORR process at the electrode interface, thus exhibiting excellent ZABs performance, which is superior to most of previously reported results, as summarized in Table S8 [59,61,64]. For flexible electronic energy equipment, it is vital to manufacture and develop quasi-solid-state ZABs [71–73]. We fabricated highly adaptable quasi-solid-state ZABs utilizing commercial zinc foil as the anode and PAM hydrogel saturated with KOH-Zn(CH3COO)2 as the quasi-solid-state electrolyte to demonstrate the advantages of air cathode with Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC [37,74]. Compared to Pt/C-RuO2 air cathode based ZAB (1.38 V), ZABs with Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC electrocatalyst had an open-circuit potential (OCP) of 1.31 V (Fig. S19). Fig. S20 depicts the as-fabricated power density curves and discharge polarization curves of ZABs. The power density of flexible Pt/C-RuO2 air cathodes is 51 mW cm−2, while the power density of Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC air cathodes is 56 mW cm−2. The ZABs with Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC air cathode has a higher specific capacity (845.6 mAh g−1) than that of Pt/C-RuO2 air cathode (596.6 mAh g−1) at a current density of 1 mA cm−2 (Fig. 7d). Fig. S21 demonstrates that the Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC-based solid-state ZAB exhibits excellent cycling stability, with steady charging (1.88 V) and discharging (1.05 V) voltages for over 177 cycles (more than 59 h) at a current density of 1 mA cm−2. Three Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC based quasi-solid-state ZABs connected in series can drive and light a red LED display while retaining the initial brightness for an extended period of time, demonstrating the practical application of quasi-solid-state ZABs (Fig. 7d inset). The Co3S4/FeS@CoFe/NC cathode-based quasi-solid-state ZAB demonstrates remarkable stability under 0°, 60°, 90°, and 180° bending conditions, as shown in Fig. 7(e), indicating its outstanding mechanical flexibility for flexible electronic applications. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have successfully constructed a self-supported bifunctional composite catalyst of bimetallic sulfide nanoparticles embedded in atomic Co/Fe doped carbon nanosheets, which can be used as an efficient air cathode for high-performance and durable rechargeable ZABs. The superior bifunctional oxygen activity of the array-type bimetallic sulfide composite catalyst can be attributed to abundant accessible active sites for interface reactions, multiphase coupling of the sulfide heterojunctions with single-atomic metal, and optimization of oxygen diffusion at the three-phase interface by super-hydrophobic feature. Our DFT calculations revealed that the coupling effect between multiphase bimetallic sulfide heterojunctions through single-atomic metal doped carbon nanosheets can reduce the shift of electron density of states center before and after oxygen adsorption and the magnetic moment of Co/Fe ions, leading to lower spin density on adsorbed oxygen. As a result, the charge/spin interactions between adsorbed oxygen and the substrate are diminished, leading to a lower oxygen adsorption energy and faster reaction kinetics. This study provides a guidance for preparation of high-performance bifunctional catalyst by multi-phase composite design and regulating oxygen electrocatalytic activity through charge-spin optimization. coredata.dc:description: Development of a high-performance bifunctional catalyst is essential for the actual implementation of zinc-air batteries in practical applications. Herein, a bifunctional cathode of Co3S4/FeS heterogeneous nanoparticles embedded in Co/Fe single-atom-loaded nitrogen-doped carbon nanosheets is designed. Cobalt-iron sulfides and single atomic sites with Co-N4/Fe-N4 configurations are confirmed to coexist on the carbon matrix by EXAFS spectroscopy. 3D self-supported super-hydrophobic multiphase composite cathode provides abundant active sites and facilitates gas–liquid-solid three-phase interface reactions, resulting in excellent electrocatalytic activity and batteries performance, i.e., an OER overpotential (η 10) of 260 mV, a half-wave potential (E 1/2) of 0.872 V for ORR, a ΔE of 0.618 V, and a discharge power density of 170 mW cm−2, a specific capacity of 816.3 mAh g−1. DFT analysis shows multiphase coupling of sulfide heterojunction through single-atomic metal doped carbon nanosheets reduces offset on center of electronic density of states before and after oxygen adsorption, and spin density of adsorbed oxygen with same spin orientation, leading to weakened charge/spin interactions between adsorbed oxygen and substrate, and a lowered oxygen adsorption energy to accelerate OER/ORR.
